prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for abandoning my oldest and closest friend who has depression because he’s a vile racist?
So my best friend who I’ve known since primary school, let’s call him Will. Will is a racist.

He was brought up in a racist household and was taught that he was racially superior to others, of course when I became friends with him when I was 5 or 6, I didn’t really know much about all of that. 

By the time we were teenagers I really began to see how racist he was; it started off with him just doing small things like if he was annoyed with someone he’d whisper to me behind that guy’s back a racial slur directed at him, so that’s pretty minor and that’s not too bad.

But it got worse, by the time we were 16, he was quite an agressive person, he would commonly get in spats, and he would often target minorities. This one time we were walking in a park and we encountered two black people in the year below. I was friends with one of the guys so I was being friendly, but Will, on the other hand, told them to leave aggressively (using many swears and racial slurs). They left in a bit of dismay and I was quite shocked and I asked him what was wrong, and he said quite simply 
“their (n-word) faces made me angry”

So at this point I wanted to distance myself from Will, but there’s another thing, Will is really depressed. He is anorexic because he’s insecure about his weight, he’s Anxious about most things, and I’m his only friend. Alongside this, he confessed to me he self harms which of course is very serious.

So yeah, last week we were in a group chat, and there was a black person in it, and Will being Will just went at this guy for no reason, and this was the final straw. I blocked him on all social media’s and I completely avoid him at school. I haven’t spoken to him since, but the fact that he is depressed and in a bad place still eats at me. AITA?
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, so I need to figure out if the person who wrote this is in the wrong. Let's start by breaking down the situation. The user's best friend, Will, has depression and several mental health issues, including anorexia, anxiety, and self-harming. But he's also a racist, with a history of using racial slurs and aggressive behavior towards minorities. The user is asking if they're in the wrong for cutting off Will after a recent incident in a group chat where Will targeted someone black.

First, I should consider the severity of Will's actions. Racism is a serious issue, and the examples given—like using racial slurs and aggressive behavior—show that Will has a pattern of harmful behavior. The user mentions that Will was brought up in a racist household, which might explain some of his behavior, but that doesn't excuse it. People are responsible for their actions, regardless of upbringing.

Then there's the mental health aspect. Will is struggling with depression and other issues, and the user is his only friend. The user might feel conflicted because they care about Will but can't tolerate his racism. The key question here is whether the user is justified in distancing themselves from Will given the harmful behavior. 

On one hand, supporting someone with mental health issues is important, but that doesn't mean one has to tolerate bigotry. On the other hand, cutting off someone who is already isolated could exacerbate their mental health problems. However, the user might feel that their own well-being is at stake if they continue to associate with someone who spreads hate. 

The user did try to distance themselves gradually, as mentioned in the escalation from subtle racism to more aggressive acts. The final incident in the group chat seems to be the breaking point. It's possible that the user is trying to protect not only themselves but also others in the group chat from Will's harmful behavior. 

But the user is also concerned about Will's mental health. However, Will's actions are a choice that affects others negatively. Mental health does not excuse bigotry. The user has a right to set boundaries to protect themselves and others from Will's harmful behavior. 

So, considering all factors, the user is not in the wrong for cutting off Will. They're standing up against racism, which is a moral stance, even if it's difficult given their past friendship. The answer should be B (No, the author is not in the wrong).
